occupation.value: Employed by Matthew Boulton, business partner of James Watt.

event.value: William WALKED to Birmingham from his home in Scotland (approx. 480km) to ask James Watt for a job.

education.value: Under William Halbert, author of a highly regarded arithmetic textbook. Murdoch excelled at mathematics.
Educated here until the age of 10.

place.place-name: kirk school, Old Cumnock, Ayrshire, Scotland

individual.note: The third of seven children and the first son to survive past infancy.

event.value: A wooden horse on wheels. A precursor of the bicycle.

employment.value: Engaged in repairs around Craikston Bridge and on the "Publick road."

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch
A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

employment.value: Designed a corn drying kiln for the Boswells.

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

employment.value: Installing a water machine for drying the coalwork. Paid £38 by Lord Auchinleck.

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch
A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

military.value: Recorded in the muster as "on furla" [furlough, presumably].

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

military.value: Recorded on the muster roll as "Sick at Perth".

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

military.value: John was almost certainly engaged at the battle of Culloden in 1746, where the gunners in Cumberland's army played a crucial role. Their disciplined fire power using grapeshot first checked and then broke the charging Highlanders.

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

military.value: John carried out military service in the Low Countries.

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

education.value: John joins the Woolwich Company of the Trains of Artillery as an apprentice.

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

military.value: John qualifies as a gunner, at one shilling and fourpence a day.

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch
A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch
A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

event.value: John Gillies and Thomas Eddington, sales representatives for John Roebuck's Carron Foundry (in Falkirk), pay John a series of visits at Bello Mill.

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

occupation.value: John takes over the running of the mill from his father.

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

note.value: Parish records at Auchinleck were not impeccably kept during John's lifetime and it is impossible to be certain about John and Anna's family. Seven children are listed in the baptismal register at Auchinleck but only six in 1833 in the family Bible held by their descendant Mrs Walton of Todmarton, and noted by MacFie. Robert's name is missing from the Bible entry, but since there is little doubt about his baptism and subsequent life it is reasonable to infer that John and Anna had seven children - two of whom, Andrew and Euphemia, died in infancy. (Source: The Third Man, 1992).

individual.alias: Mrs. Bruce (even though she was unmarried)
individual.occupation: Took over as housekeeper at Auchinleck (and later on at Boswell's residence in London) from her mother, and also became nurse to James Boswell's own children.

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch
A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

occupation.value: Overseer/Agent of the Boswell's estate in Auchinleck. As was his father, before him.

source-citation.page: A biography of the Scottish inventor, William Murdoch

individual.note: James and Jean had at least 11 children, 9 of whom survived through infancy.

source-citation.page: Extracted Church of England Parish Records; Title: Various publications of parish and probate records

residence.value: Moved to live with his twin sister, Jean, in Ardrossan, after the death of their brother John.

occupation.value: A year after the death of his brother, and business partner, John, Andrew disposed of their business.

residence.value: The poem "To a Haggis", was written in Andrew's home by Robert Bruce.

event.value: A friend of Robert Burns, the poet.

occupation.value: Trading as John Bruce & Co. hardware merchants. John was in partnership with his younger brother Andrew and James Cooper, a jeweller.
A servant to the Boswell family on their estate in Auchinleck until October 1772.

individual.note: John and Catherine had at least 4 children, born between 1776 and 1786 at 10 Princes Street.

source-citation.page: Extracted Church of England Parish Records; Title: Various publications of parish and probate records

individual.note: One of Annabella's great-grandson's was Sir Robert Bruce Lockhart (1887-1970), author of Memoirs of a British Agent, 1932.
